body: How are these changes comparable to what Henry has done to fine tune performance (see description on the JIRA)? Have we understood the implication of changing the cache size on a variety of workloads? We are in the middle of doing performance tests to understand this behaviour, I wouldn't recommend lowering these values just yet. Thanks.
@enothereska this task has nothing to do with performance tuning. It is about lowering some settings so that by default we are more conservative on memory.
@rnpridgeon I created KAFKA-4758 for this issue. Would you mind changing the title to include "KAFKA-4758: ..."? Thanks!
@hachikuji , done. Sorry about that, I'll make sure to open a Jira prior to making a Pull Request next time
@guozhangwang Updated.

jeyhun.karimov
see link in Jeyhun's comment :)

+1 for change. Currently, metadata TimeoutException doesn't include underlying cause (UNKNOWN_TOPIC_OR_PARTITION, LEADER_NOT_AVAILABLE) etc.  It will be good if we can include this. This can be done in another JIRA/PR.

Is there any risk that suppressing the log message will have the opposite problem of concealing the fact that the topic doesn't exist (you may have to search way back in the history to find the message)? Or maybe if we added more information to the TimeoutException as suggested by @omkreddy, then we could reduce the log level to DEBUG?

Thanks for the patch @jozi-k , could you rebase on latest trunk as well?
@Aegeaner @lindong28 I'd suggest change the signature of `validateValue` to take `Field` and `Object` as the parameter. BTW is this a public API? cc @ewencp

Thanks for the fast fix! 
I tested my code with the pull request and it works without exception.
I will rebase, that is not a problem. This is still WIP so all TODOs in the code should be cleared, I just wanted to have some reaction first if I am on the right track.
@guozhangwang   It's not a public API but is used quite often in connect schema tests. Kafka Connect exposed REST api to validate configs.

As per meta comment. Originally I actually wanted to add xxView to all values that work with mutable.Map as mapValues changes would be lost in original mutable.Map. But there are also use cases where we do not need mutable.Map at all and calling mapValues on immutable.Map is fine as there is no side effect. When I actually look through all usages of mapValues I could rewrite all of them to be used on immutable.Map (btw, this is reason why I use .toMap on mutable.Map to make it immutable) and there is no need to add "View" suffix to our code.

Jenkins states that the build fails, but clicking on the "Details" link returns a 404.  I suspect that Jenkins is broken?  Else, how can I see if the changes I brought break anything?  They are very minor and actually improve the code by adding quotes to all paths.
